I don't qualify to comment.

No, not necessarily wondering but thinking that in your grandfather's case, what was most likely a strong influence was the non-dietary factors that aided him to have a long life. What about the cleaner air he breathed and the fresher water? What about the close companions and likely strong social bonds that helped?

Many of us breathe polluted air, drink marginal water and have limited (to put it euphemistically) social lives. I think these deficiencies should be factored in to why we live shorter lives than, say, your grandfather did.

No, it does not make me wonder.

Your grandfather had the most healthful diet known, as shown in multiple studies: the Mediterranean diet.

There is nothing wrong with pasta twice a day (we are talking with fresh toppings here, not boxed mac & cheese), bread, coffee or milk in moderation. Add to that abundant fresh fruit, vegetables and grains as I am sure he ate with that pasta, a culture of enjoying your food and its varied tastes (not gulping down without thought while at the computer or watching TV), and you have an excellent diet.

My grandmother lived to be 96, independent until the end. She put sugar on tomatoes, sugar in her daily three cups of tea. She ate whatever she wanted, usually in small amounts. She did not exercise, but was a painter and a reader. She was seldom stressed by anything and took a daily afternoon nap.

My sister in law, a health nut, who stressed about every detail and worried if she did not make it to her exercise class, died recently from brain cancer at age 56.

It certainly does make you wonder.

I was born and raised on a farm on the east coast of Sicily, overlooking the Ionian Sea and then, later, on a large, working vegetable farm just outside of Boston.

When I watched all of the outlandish contortions, based on little or no facts, people have made over the years with regard to what they eat, I can only think of my grandfather.

He stopped smoking at 80 and lived to be 90, never sick a day in his life. He ate pasta twice a day and drank wine with every meal. His breakfast fresh bread dunked in strong espresso and boiled milk with big, heaping spoonfuls of sugar, would make most people run for the hills.

If it were only my grandfather one could chalk it up to good luck, except, there's an entire village of my grandfather's back in Sicily, many of whom I know personally.

They've never put almond milk to their lips, denied themselves a nice dish of friend squid, or suffered through a kale smoothie and are much healthier than the people that do.

Makes you wonder, no?

See Dr. Kelly's reply among the comments to this piece. Though AA doesn't conduct research, the National Institutes of Health conducted extensive research on AA in the 1990's. The benefits of AA are well-recognized for those that will will commit to it.

There is an approach in psychology called "harm reduction" which seeks a variety of approaches in addition to total abstinence. Since AA is not based on research (since it doesn't conduct research) we have no evidence that abstinence is the only, or even the best outcome for all situations. In a "harm reduction" model, each case is viewed individually, looking at factors such as type of use, age of use, chronicity, severity, legal factors (DUI, violence, drug use/sales, etc.) Further, arguing over the word "alcoholic" can be detrimental (if the answer is a yes/no) where a better question is to look at if, when and how alcohol (or other drug) creates a problem in one's life.

Some people find much power in AA, and this is a very good approach for them, but it is not the "only." If anyone is concerned about alcohol/drug use they should seek a trained professional to discuss this, but not to look for yes/no alcoholism or even yes abstinence/no abstinence. Personalized professional treatment gives many options.And, yes, some people do stop, or cut back,on their own.

I, too, have prosopagnosia. I've sometimes wondered if my own case is related to having had 20/00 vision or worse until I was 12 years old & got glasses. I couldn't see any facial features clearly unless the person was right up close, and never had a notion that it might be possible to connect faces to who a person was.

I recall assuming that people were just pretending to enjoy plays and sports, since it seemed obvious that it was impossible to tell one dramatic character from any other of the same gender and age, and ditto for the vague shapes running around in alleged patterns on the football field.

I do have vivid recall of photographs, including photos of faces. Different part of the brain...

@Grouch and havnear.  Long term I can see it.  But right now manufacturing centers all of a sudden shifting because of the  increases in labor saving would be costly.  Think about the IP involved, the amount of fixed assets and sunk cost.  I mean why haven't US automakers shifted their production entirely out of the US?  I'm curious.  I understand Prof. K and Grouch's argument of why they don't like the Euro from the New K perspective.  But getting off the Euro at this stage would also be costly, or am I missing something?  Lastly even if they all of sudden shifted to internal currencies what exports would Greece produce to even out these trade imbalances.  I understand the idea of floating currency and macro devaluations that would occur with their own currencies, but from a practical perspective they would still have to produce quality goods and services and I'm not sure that would happen overnight as Krugman seems to believe.  Allowing larger inflation in the core (Germany) seems like a more practical approach.

"Dr K never said the Euro would collapse."

Not true. He repeatedly speculated about the break up of the Eurozone and the exit of some of the Southern peripherals. And he urged that course of action. He's essentially admitted above and in other comment that he underestimated the strength of the political, economic, institutional and legal factors that have kept it together. Viz.

" But as a europessimist, I do have to admit that it’s now possible to see how this could work."

Dr Krugman's shout-out to Mario Draghi might be seen as a weasel response to the surprising determination of Europeans to remain attached to Euro at any cost, BUT...

Dr K never said the Euro would collapse. He did say that leaving the Euro would be better for some countries, but that the logistics of doing so were too daunting. So it was/is unlikely that any country would exit.

But the cost of remaining is devastating. Let's play this forward.

5.5% unemployment in Germany and 10%+ everywhere else is rapidly becoming the norm, due to "sticky wages" effect. Generous UE benefits can sustain that high level for quite some time.

But not forever. Eventually, calls for cutting benefits in the despised Southern countries could un-stick wages, resulting in dramatically unequal distribution of wealth.

We could easily compare this future EU to the states of the US. Just as NYer's earn more than Alabamans, Germans will earn more tha Spaniards.

Spaniards will build automobiles nearly as well as Germans, but at significantly lower cost. Will automakers take advantage of this advantage? Will other industries? When the cost saving exceeds the penalties of moving production, will industry remain nationalstic? Will Labor Unions hold up in poor countries?

This is playing out now in the US.

Predictably the editorial is selective in its treatment of the Snowden affair, clearly aimed at diverting responsibility from the Obama Administration, responsible for the management of the NSA, to Congress as the branch of government bearing the brunt of the blame. So much for the claim by Candidate Obama of a transparent administration and for the Administration's huge expansion of the NSA remit. That Mr Clapper in particular lied to Congress, and that the Administration initially lied as to the extent of this disgraceful NSA conduct at home and abroad, is never an excuse, nor does it exonerate Snowden, nor the Obama Administration for unconstitutional acts.

Snowden committed treasonous, traitorous activities when he violated the trust placed in him, no matter if he was ineptly selected, supervised, or claims to have done a patriotic act. As to "the shrill brigade of his critics", their reaction has, thus far, been measured, lawful, and critical of the identified responsible parties.

Clemency is far beyond the pale; If Snowden has a backbone, or even a modicum of guts, he will throw himself at the mercy of the US Judicial system, and win or lose, take the outcome as his just desserts.

That the NYT sees fit to champion Snowden is disappointing and is aimed at diverting attention away from the lawful responsibility of the Obama Administration than any other consideration. The buck has never stopped at the desk in the oval office yet, since '09. It is time that it did.

What the NSA has been doing is the culmination of decades of bad judgment, bad legislation, and no oversight. History will judge President Obama's part in this story, for sure. We would not have known, were it not for the risk Snowden took to let it be known.

President Obama alone cannot fix this. There isn't a majority in Congress that will fix this. It is up to the voters to ask a lot more questions now and vote accordingly.

Agreed -- but it won't stop diet nuttery, which is deeply ingrained in our culture (going back to the 19th century if not longer, and stuff like breathariaism or Dr. Kellogg's health sanitariums).

Though there are no guarantees of long life from any eating regime, you certainly would NOT know that from the books, TV commercials and websites out there -- often blatantly promising everything from the body of a teenage gymnast, to eternal sexual appeal, to extended lifespans and freedom from diabetes and cancer, if only you "eat as they tell you to".
Beautifully stated, Jay Kallio!

There are countless people who maintain a purist "health food nut" lifestyle and get sick, and many people who live a polluted, high fat, sugar laden, hedonistic lifestyle who stay healthy and live long. The moral of the story? We cannot control everything, no matter how hard we try.

Whether our illnesses and deaths are determined by genes, environment, or lifestyles is still a crapshoot, and no amount of positive thinking, asceticism, or studied science (which in so many ways is still in it's infancy) can predict outcomes. I try to stack the deck in my favor by moderation and plenty of fruits and vegetables, a daily walk, and 10 minutes of meditation, but otherwise am gentle with myself and others. We simply do not understand what works to prevent illness yet.

No one can completely control whether we become ill, injured, or disabled, which is why we need single payer, universal health care in the US. We judge it to be the province of government to try to protect citizens from the effects of war, crime, epidemics, fires, terrorism, hurricanes, tornadoes, etc., why this disconnect on individual's medical catastrophes? We need to affirm health care as a human right, like the vast majority of other nations, most of whom have better health outcomes for their citizens than our most wealthy country does. It's the humane thing to do.

"It makes no logical sense to exchange fruits and vegetables for unhealthy sweets like Twinkies. They all contain sugar, which as the dentist mentioned affect the teeth. Was he being sarcastic? "

Um...yes? The point he's making is that just because it's something we presume healthy, doesn't necessarily it is, or it is under every and all circumstance. The entire point of the essay is that her dietary habits are a core part of her identity and she needs to re-examine it in light of a medical diagnosis, and because of she overlooked the oral hygiene aspect of her diet.

Even if it's unhealthy, the author feels admiration for the certitude in her husband's diet -- or complete lack thereof. Her world was turned upside down, and whether or not she can finesse the situation later is to miss the fundamental purpose of the essay. In the end, she eats the Twinkie not because it's medical advice, but because it's a relic of something reliable and steady.

And also, because this is apparently necessary in the utterly humorless comments section of the NYT, since it's funny. A health nut eats a Twinkie, this would be the obvious irony. Laugh, people.

There is a big difference between juices and smoothies - in general, smoothies (made by blending whole fruits and/or vegetables) are much healthier than juices. The process of juicing removes fiber, and increases the rapidity with which the natural sugars of fruits and vegetables are absorbed. Our bodies need fiber, and benefit from low glycemic index foods. Perhaps blending also helps protect teeth as opposed to juicing - it would be an interesting topic to investigate further.

It makes no logical sense to exchange fruits and vegetables for unhealthy sweets like Twinkies. They all contain sugar, which as the dentist mentioned affect the teeth. Was he being sarcastic? Current science tells us it's essential for our health that we eat lots of fruits and vegetables, avoid processed foods, and brush our teeth regularly, so switching to chocolate and cola is, in my opinion, poor advice. I have heard that lemon or lime in water erodes enamel; perhaps drinking water with these freshly squeezed fruits contributes not only to the wearing down of the enamel, but also makes the teeth more vulnerable to cavities.

For medical conditions such as hypothyroidism, consult a doctor who is extremely knowledgeable about the health benefits of food and who has extensive experience modifying diets for various conditions. Dr. Fuhrman of Eat to Live is one who comes to mind. Don't be content with looking up information on the Internet. Best of luck in your search for solutions.
